properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, expected Monday and Tuesday. Total Rainfall: Local rainfall amounts possibly exceeding 50 mm. Locations: Mainland Nova Scotia and Fundy coast of New Brunswick Time frame: Monday morning to Tuesday afternoon, with more rain possible for Tuesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected over these regions through Sunday evening. Snow will begin early Sunday morning and is expected to intensify during the day. Flurries at times heavy and blowing snow are also possible as the cold front passes in the second half of the day, which could significantly reduce visibility. In addition, temperatures will drop rapidly after its passage. Conditions should gradually improve overnight Sunday night, but further snowfall accumulations are expected on Monday. Travel conditions could be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T17:36:14-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow is falling in west-central parts of the province. The snow is expected to gradually move southwards tonight and is forecast to end from north to south beginning early Sunday morning. In the Crowsnest Pass region, snow is expected to begin early this evening with the highest snowfall amounts focused near Waterton Lakes National Park. In the Cypress Hills region, snow is forecast to begin this evening, with the more intense band of snow moving through the region overnight. General amounts of 10 to 20 cm are forecast, although amounts may reach 30 cm in localized areas near the B.C. and Alberta-USA border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T14:25:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-07T22:26:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3585430305.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall overnight into Sunday. Snow is moving in from the west as expected and will persist for much of Sunday. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are likely, with a few pockets of 10 to 15 cm possible especially near the Quebec border. The snow should taper off by Sunday evening. In addition to the snowfall, there is a risk of a brief but intense snow squall Sunday as a sharp Arctic cold front moves through. Visibility may suddenly drop to near zero with this snow squall. Snow squall watches and warnings may be issued if necessary. Road conditions are likely to be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T21:34:48-00:00

properties.Summary:

A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: local snowfall possibly reaching 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Locations: Inverness County - south of Mabou, Victoria county, Antigonish county, and Kings county, Prince Edward Island. Time frame: until this afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The Kivalliq coastline may see periods of blowing snow tonight into Sunday as moderate northwest winds persist through the region. Later on Sunday, the winds will strengthen and the region will enter a prolonged period with north-northwest winds of 40 to 50 km/h and gusts as high as 70 km/h. These strong winds are expected to persist until Wednesday. These winds will produce widespread blowing snow across the region and likely result in periods of dangerous overland travel. There is some uncertainty as to whether or not a full-fledged blizzard will develop over the region, or if instead the blowing snow will be more localized in nature. The situation will continue to be assessed and blizzard warnings may be issued if needed. The coastal Kivalliq communities should nonetheless be prepared for a multi-day period of strong northerly winds that will very likely produce, at least, periods of near-blizzard conditions from late Sunday to Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T19:41:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T03:42:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3326749683.2019
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 15 to possibly 30 cm over the Highlands. Maximum Wind Gusts: 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Location: Inverness County - Mabou and north, including the Highlands. Timespan: until this afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. The first major cold wave of the winter has moved into portions of the northern prairies and is expected to persist well into next week. Wind chills during the overnight periods will reach the minus 45 to minus 50 range in northern Saskatchewan. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. On Sunday, moderate northwesterly winds will produce periods of blowing snow through much of the day in Baker Lake. Winds will strengthen into the 50 to 60 km/h range on Sunday afternoon, worsening the blowing snow and creating blizzard conditions. The blizzard is expected to persist through Sunday night with some improvement Monday morning. Periods of blowing snow will continue to be possible later Monday into Monday night. While it is uncertain at this point, indications are that blizzard conditions may redevelop for Tuesday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T19:39:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T03:40:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2425744980.2019
Area: Baker Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A weak disturbance crossing northern Yukon will give strong east winds of 50 km/h gusting to 70 near the Richardson Mountains overnight and Sunday morning. These strong winds will give reduced visibility in blowing snow and cold wind chills near minus 30. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic air mass moving into northern Manitoba will send temperatures plummeting into the -30 to -35C range in the Tadoule Lake and Brochet regions tonight. Combined with northwesterly winds near 15 km/h, extreme wind chill values near -45 have developed and will persist into Sunday morning. Some improvement in wind chills is expected by midday Sunday, but extreme values will likely return Sunday night and continue off and on until at least mid-week. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T19:45:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T03:46:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2255885005.2019
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First extreme cold event of the season. Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 45 are expected overnight into Sunday morning. Northwest winds near 30 km/h are pumping in bitterly cold air from the Arctic tonight. These winds combined with overnight lows near -30 degrees celsius will produce windchill values near -45. Wind chill values will become less extreme during the day Sunday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong low pressure system will track north into western Hudson Strait today. As it approaches, very strong southeast winds and snow will develop over southern Baffin Island, with the worst conditions expected at Kimmirut. Blizzard conditions are likely to develop at Kimmirut late this morning and persist throughout the afternoon and evening with gradual improvement beginning overnight. Southeast winds gusting to 90 km/h combined with falling snow will give visibilities of 400 metres or less during the blizzard. Total snowfall amounts will be in the 10 to 20 cm range. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T01:25:47-00:00
